title: Going Global with Mobile App Development: Enabling the Connected Enterprise
segmentation: So I want to introduce to you the Multilingual App Toolkit.
This is a toolkit that uses the same workflow as the one that we did.
Tributed to the Windows 8 store.
This one is an extension to that that supports the Windows Phone we just released this March 3rd and the bits went live on the 4th day with the MSDN content so forth.

One of the things that we think is really important when you're developing any kind of an application is your ability to, as a developer in your language, understand the implications in other languages that you may not speak, and so as we did for the Windows 8 store apps, we've integrated a pseudo localization component to the Phone 8 toolkit as well, and for those of you who.
Don't know what pseudo localization is, anybody?
Brilliant.
Um?
It's pretty simple, straightforward in your development environment where you're speaking in your language to see how you may have some too many characters you may have truncations.
Typical localizability issues are easy to see.
See can change your format because on a mobile device there are only so many pixels.

So we also have file translation, export and import built right into the toolkit allows you to send your resources out to translation services, whether professional, family and friends, your neighbor or yourself and you just need to have some file management for that.
And I'll show some of that.
We have an editor as well.
It's a very simple string editor localization editor that's included allows you to.
Work with the same files that we export that are in excellent format.

And then we also have an integrated Microsoft Translator service built into that editor so that it's quite simple to get those translations suggestions as noted in the keynote translations from machine machines can be quite good or not quite as good depending upon the languages you're working with or the tone.
If you're working with a specific tone.
The machine translation might be a bit too formal or a little bit awkward, so.
We think of them as great starting point suggestions.
Sometimes it's good enough.
It's up to you to decide what that is, but we provide that as a service within the editor.
So.
In Windows Phone 8 in the toolkit.
Making the tools available.
Making the apps available internationally was OK, but developers really wanted to be better.
Make it easier to get into more than one marketplace.
So this is kind of what happens.
You create a new phone project.
You add bindings to your resources.
Yeah, you're rocking cool features.
And then you test the app in your language.
OK, you know what you're doing so far.
Then you get additional resource files.
You get the Red X files for each language localized.
You test your app in a lot of different languages that you may not read or know.
I discover bugs that require resource changes.
You apply resource changes across all the additional resource files, so you keep everything up to date.
Alot of manual work.
And then you get those res X files relocalized and restart testing.
Rinse and repeat.
It takes a lot of handholding of those apps to be able to ship in more than one language.
Well, I want to demo today in this toolkit.
Will show how we're trying to make it a little bit easier, so I'm going to start with the ready for localization Windows Phone 8 app.
I'm going to add support for French.
I'll show that import and export to clip so you can see what that looks like, how that's done.
I'll show you that I'm simply storing my translation files in the cloud and Sky drive.
I'll show that same app in Windows 8 with support French and then I'll reuse an existing translation from the phone app supporting the Windows Store version.

So very high level sort of an end to end scenario on how a developer can create a Windows 8 app for the phone, how they can get it translated out like an export that translation to some location in the cloud, or whatever they want to do, and then how they can very easily.
Consume that in their equivalent Windows 8 Store app.
To make life just a bit easier now where this is important for developers, is that.
In the enterprise, and this is something that your was going to talk about.
He couldn't be with us today due to some illness.
In the enterprise, there's something called bring your own device where it pros are faced with the fact that we all have a variety of devices in our pockets.
We want to use them.
We have devices that don't quite fit in pockets, but they're smaller than laptops and we have devices that are laptops.
We're bringing a lot of devices into the enterprise and in the past that was something that didn't work.
The enterprise is shifting and changing to try and take care of that and still maintain security and protocols and productivity.
And so if you're developing for the enterprise, being able to develop for.
Multi device is really important.
Doing it in an enterprise means that it must be multilingual because by the nature of the term enterprise you are a multilingual entity.
And so that's part of what we were thinking about.
When you're going to work, going to have the other talk that we're going to have this morning.
This piece supports that scenario.
It also supports any app developer who thinks that they want to reach across devices on a cool idea they've got.
So I think it carries beyond the initial enterprise scenario, but I wanted to call that out as well.
Let me go ahead.
OK.
I'm in the Visual Studio IDE.
You can see that there's a basic phone app program here.
I've also started.
Windows Phone emulator and it's running.
Time so you can.
I can just go ahead and move that around as you understand that that looks like a Windows Phone emulating it.
So the first thing I'm going to do?
As I'm going to go to my tool section where I have downloaded and installed this extension.
Back to that called the Multilingual App Toolkit.
And I'm going to enable it.
This toolkit, while I'm working in the ultimate SKU of Windows Studio 2012 here the toolkits available for all SKUs and including all the express cues, so it's no cost.
OK, so you can see something happened under resources.
I've got an app resources, QPS, Peel, Oak dot XLS.
So there's an excellent file.
It now is the master.
You can see that the Red X file is owned by it.
The Q PSP look is our locale for pseudo localization and so we can go ahead and use it as the language creates, though pretty simply.
Generate the translations if we want right there.
OK, and so I now have a pseudo localized file that I could go ahead and run and you see the Super localized strings, but I wanted to show you today was how to add translation languages.
So I will pick one I said I was going to French.
You'll note in this in this dialog that you see some notations for the Microsoft Translator service.
That's dynamic, as the translator service adds more language pairs.
This language list will be automatically updated to support them.
OK, you can now see that I have an app resources Fr Fr Excel file.
And so I'm going to go ahead and rebuild.
The app which will populate that file and that file is created.
It's an empty XLA file when I run build, which is what everything is tide to.
Then it goes ahead and puts the source terms into and generates it.
It's pretty important that I go ahead and get a. I get a translation.
I have one right here on Sky Drive.
You see that it says Sky drive up here.
I'm gonna go ahead and get that translation.
Build.
OK.
So I've got the emulator running down here.
See that I've got a number of solutions here.
Go ahead and run our work app.
You can see it's a very simple thing.
I just wanted to demonstrate.
A notion of some enterprise apps that you could have if your nightie.
You can see there in English.
Settings.
Windows Phone.
Language settings.
And we're going to wait a minute as the emulator restarts.
I'm running a hard drive, not an SSD, so it's a little bit slower than if I had slightly faster hardware to run on.
I could show you the Red X files.
I can show you the excellent files that you would see.
The translations have been imported, generated and so on.
But right now, let's just continue to go with looking at a higher level.
This is the editor that we that I showed you earlier.
Or talked about earlier.
Very simple tool where you can see you've got source and translation.
This was the.
Service going into the Microsoft Translator.
To account of network connectivity, we have, yeah, Charles.
Question.
Yeah as a service.
We had network access earlier this morning.
We'll see how it goes.
Yeah.
No, we don't have a connection, so we're not gonna be able to demonstrate that.
So we're going to go ahead and go to the tablet.
My other project.
Go through the same basic process where I'm going to go ahead and enable the toolkit.
In this case, you see that there's a folder called Multilingual Resources.
Underneath it, there's tablet APK PSP.
Locate XL F. This is how we're managing it.
The workflow is that when I go ahead an ad.
Translation languages here.
Can go through the same process.
There we are.
So you can see tablet_Fr dash, Fr dot XLF is created.
And so this was the point that I wanted to show was the ability to recycle.
So you can go to the cloud.
You can go wherever you've got the file.
It was created over in the phone side.
We open it up.
Well it populated in there.
Hillary build.
And then run it.
And who's your app?
See it's in English.
Back French.
But that is is in the Windows 8.
There's language, profane language preferences settings, and you can go ahead and add as many languages as you want, and then set them for fall back.
In this case I had English as my primary language.
In French is a secondary one, I just changed the order.
OK, so go ahead and run again.
And because I lost the translation file, apparently it disappeared.
It's not showing up in French and I don't have the translator service available, so I can't show machine translation version.
So you have to take my word for it that it actually went through that process.
Unfortunately, I can't demonstrate that.
The point being that.
It's pretty straightforward in the workflow to move from a phone.
To another device.
This was a tablet that I was emulating.
You can, once you're over on the PC side, it's whatever form factor you want there.
And so you can share the file, because this is an excellent format and you can put it in the cloud or you can Mail it, which is another demonstration that I can show very quickly.
I can take it and I could send a translation.
And you can see file folder location, which is where I could put it locally on a network share.
Or I can put it in the cloud.
Or I can email it.
If I email it to somebody.
You can see this attachment.
There's also a link in the email, and that link is to whoever you're sending it to.
Perhaps it is somebody that's an informal language expert for you that has no idea about how to develop.
Applications, but they do have some language skills.
If they click on the link and they don't have Visual Studio installed, we will simply install the editor instead so they can go ahead and work with that file and put their translations in.
If you've given them a machine translation version as well, they'll be able to write over that and create a better translation where needed, and then go ahead and Mail it back to you.
So it's as simple as sending it by email or putting it on the cloud to get those extra files out.
And then of course in the cases where there are other platforms that you need to support.
Or other translators that you want to work with.
X lift is a pretty easy format for people to open up and work with either just by reading it in some kind of text editor or something that supports XML translation services.
Understand excellent, very well.
We've worked with a lot of the translator services.
Large and small to understand.
Our implementation of this to make sure that they can't work with it.
Will continue to work with very active in TC for X LIF to help assure that there's interoperability across.
Platforms.
So that is my presentation.
I apologize for not being able to show you French figure that one out later today, but not at your expense.
OK.
Thank you.
